section.title: Overview
section.para: Beginning with version 0.9, the database engine supports basic user authentication and access control. Access control loosely resembles Unix conventions, so Unix users should be familiar with this.
Access control is disabled unless you set a password for the superuser (see below). Write access is granted to everyone, so please be careful about exposing your server to the world.

eXist organizes users in groups. It has different permission sets for the user, the group and the rest of the world. Every user may be a member of several groups. The "dba" group is a special group reserved to database administrators. Only "dba" users are allowed to create or remove users or change permissions for other users.

Information on users is stored in database collection /db/system in the special XML file /db/system/users.xml, which is created on database startup. By default, the /db/system collection is only readable for "dba" users, but you may choose to change this.

Passwords are stored as MD5 digests. Whenever a user enters his password, the database generates an MD5 for it and compares it to the digest stored in users.xml. It is rather difficult to guess the original password from the MD5 string, so passwords should be sufficiently secure.

Every resource in the database is owned by a user and by a group. By default, the owner is set to the user creating the resource and his primary group. eXist manages different permissions for the owner, the owner group and others. Only the owner of the resource or dba users are allowed to change these permissions.

eXist provides an XML:DB service interface to manipulate permissions and manage users. The interactive client uses this interface to implement a set of commands which we will use in the next sections.

section.title: Change the Superuser Password
section.para: When the database is started for the first time, two default users are created: "admin" and "guest". "admin" is a member of the dba group and thus has superuser rights.

At database creation time, the "admin" password is null. This means that access to eXist is granted to everyone. To enable access control you have to set a password for the "admin" user. You may use the interactive client or the administrative web interface to do so. The client's graphical user interface has a dialog for user management. It is shown below:
If you prefer the shell mode, use the passwd command to set a new password for the superuser:

example.title: Set a password for the superuser
example.screen: type help or ? for help. exist:/db>passwd admin password: somepass re-enter password: somepass exist:/db>quit

section.para: Once a password has been set for the superuser, access control is enabled. To start the shell-mode client as superuser you will now have to specify the -u option, e.g.:

The other default user, "guest", has password "guest". The guest identity is internally assigned to all clients which have not authenticated themselves. For example, the Xincon WebDAV interface does not support authentication, so "guest" is assumed by default. This is certainly a source of confusion and you have to be careful about read/write permissions if you intend to use WebDAV.

section.title: Creating Users
section.para: The adduser shell-command allows you to create additional users. The command asks for a password and a list of groups to which the user should belong. An example is shown below:

example.title: Creating a New User
example.screen: exist:/db/shakespeare>adduser wolf password: xxxxxxxx re-enter password: xxxxxxxx enter groups: users

section.para: The command users displays a list of all known database users.

section.title: Resource Permissions
section.para: The interactive client displays the permissions assigned to each resource (if you have set the permissions=true property in the client.properties file). An example is shown below:

example.title: Permissions
example.screen: exist:/db/shakespeare/plays>ls -rwur-ur-- admin dba hamlet.xml -rwur-ur-- admin dba macbeth.xml -rwur-ur-- wolf users r_and_j.xml -rwur-ur-- admin dba shakes.xsl exist:/db/shakespeare/plays>

section.para: In this example listing, all files except r_and_j.xml are owned by user "admin" and group "dba". Currently, there are three different permissions: read, write and update.

listitem.para: permission to read or query a file or list the contents of a collection. If the read permission is not set on a collection, you will not be able to see the collection contents. The files in the collection will also not be evaluated during XPath processing.
permission to remove or update a file or add a new file or subcollection to a collection.

permission to update an existing file, either by using XUpdate or by replacing the entire document. Removing the file is not allowed unless the write permission is granted. Also, if a user has only update permissions for a collection, he will not be allowed to create new files in it.

section.para: Permissions for collections are not inherited by sub-collections, i.e. you may have write permissions for some collections though you don't have them for the parent collection.

The interactive client displays permissions similar to the Unix ls -l. In case you are not familiar with this: The first char in, for example, -rwur-ur-- shows the type of the resource: it is set to minus (-) for documents and "d" for collections. The next three chars show the permissions for the user: you will see a minus here if a permission is denied, r, w or u if the permission is granted. This pattern is repeated for group and world, i.e. the next three chars represent group permissions, the last three chars show permissions granted to others.
-rwur-ur-- is the default setting for every newly created resource, i.e. group has read/update permissions, but not write permissions; others are only allowed to read.
The database root collection /db by default has permissions set to -rwurwurwu, i.e. full access is granted to everyone.

section.para: Permissions can be changed either through the Edit Properties dialog in the client GUI or with the chmod command in the shell window. The Edit Properties dialog is shown below:

section.title: Changing Resource Ownership
section.para: Only the owner has full control over a resource. It is thus sometimes important to be able to change the ownership. The client provides the chown command to do this. The command expects three arguments:
As for chmod, the resource argument is optional: if skipped, chown will be applied to the current collection. To change the owner of the file r_and_j.xml you may do:

example.title: Changing Ownership
example.screen: exist:/db/shakespeare/plays>chown wolf users r_and_j.xml exist:/db/shakespeare/plays>ls -rwur-ur-- admin dba hamlet.xml -rwur-ur-- admin dba macbeth.xml -rwur-ur-- wolf users r_and_j.xml -rwur-ur-- admin dba shakes.xsl exist:/db/shakespeare/plays>

section.title: Authentication and Cocoon
section.para: Cocoon uses the XML:DB API to access eXist. Cocoon thus has to authenticate the user like any other XML:DB based application. To make this easier, eXist contains a Cocoon action for the login task: XMLDBSessionLoginAction. The action presents a login form, checks the entered user and password against the database and stores them to a newly created HTTP session. As long as the session remains valid, no further login will be required. You should probably read the document about actions in Cocoon's documentation to fully understand how actions work. The following snippet shows a small example from Cocoon's sitemap.xmap configuration:

example.title: sitemap.xmap snippet
example.screen: <!-- this is a protected resource: it uses the xmldb-login action to authenticate a user against the database --> <map:match pattern="xadmin.xsp"> <map:act src="xmldb:exist:///db" type="xmldb-login"> <map:generate src="xadmin.xsp" type="serverpages"/> <map:transform type="cinclude"> <map:parameter name="use-request-parameters" value="true"/> </map:transform> <map:transform src="stylesheets/doc2html-2.xsl"> <map:parameter name="use-request-parameters" value="true"/> </map:transform> <map:serialize encoding="UTF-8" type="xhtml"/> </map:act> <!-- no session found: display login form --> <map:generate src="login.xml"/> <map:transform type="cinclude"/> <map:transform src="stylesheets/doc2html-2.xsl"/> <map:serialize type="xhtml"/> </map:match>
